Homewood Eleven, Undefeated, Will Find No Soft
Pickings Tonight
WESTMINSTER GRIDDERS ARE STRONGER
Hopkins Line-Up For Night
Clash At 8 P. M., To
Be Intact
There won't be any soft pickings for Hopkins tonight, when
Western Maryland's eleven steps
on the field. Those Westminster
boys' ability will demand the
greatest respect from the Jays.
For several seasons the Green
Terrors have been represented by
teams that have tackled one
major opponent after the other
and still they've come out the
victor. Two years ago, they went
through the season without either a
loss or a tie.
Terrors Swamped st. John's
This year it seemed that the
Terrors were in for another
banner season, but the forecasts
did not turn out to be very
accurate.
Georgetown humbled
them 25-7, but only after a great
rally in the last quarter.
After the Washington and Jefferson tussle Western Maryland was
seized with that football enigma,
m1ury. Koppe, their mighty fullback, had to watch the Duquesne
game from the sidelines, but the
Terrors managed to play a scoreless
tie.
Lost To Boston College
More injuries resulted from
this and the Loyola game until
as many as four regulars were
incapacitated. Still Coac;h Harlow was able to put a team on
the field, last Saturday, that was
strong ·enough to fight but lose
by a 19-13 score to a smart Boston College eleven.
Tonight, it seems probable
that Western Maryland will
again be able to present its fullest strength.
Most of the injured men-Sadusky, Wallace,
Kleinman and perhaps Joneshave
recuperated
sufficiently
from their ailments to get back
into gridiron paraphenalia.
To-Nite's Game A Toss-Up
. means t h at H op k"ms w11··1
Th 1s
tackle its toughest opponent to
date. The line-plunging ability
of Koppe is, already a byword in
these Parts' W hile the trick)' balltoting of Jimmy Dunne will undoubtedly add several thrills to
the contest.
Fortunately the Jay line-up
will again be intact. Captain
Helm will be back at his center
post while Pete Reynolds' hand
injury has just about healed.
Despite the powerful offense
that Hopkins displayed last week,
our respect for Western Maryland's strength, displayed against
stronger opponents than the
Jays have encountered, permits
us to go no further than say we
hope the Black and Blue will retain its clear slate.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 13, 1931

Black and Blue Jay
Eleven Leads In State
Scoring Race
· Augmented by the overwhelming
score of the game with American
University, the undefeated Johns
Hopkins University football team
took the lead this week in the Free
State scoring race. Loyola, with
II8 points, is still way behind the
Jays who have garnered 150 points.
The University of Maryland is next
with 105 points.
The Homewood gridders have
had 32 points scored against them ;
Maryland, 71 ; Loyola, 47.

WAS ACTIVE IN
PRINCETON THEATRE
Herne' s Breaking A way From
Melodrama To Be Considered In Talk
S. Blaine Ewing, instructor in
English at the Johns Hopkins University, will lecture next Monday
at 8 :3o P. M., at the Playshop, on
"American Drama at the End of
the Nineteenth Century."
In his lecture, Mr. Ewing, who
has been at the Hopkins since 1930,
will speak of the attempt of James
A. Herne, author of "Margaret
Fleming," to break away from the
absurd melodrama so rampant at
that period. Berne's plays dealt
with people who were living. On
the other hand, it was pointed out,
Herne was not a realist in the sense
that Maxwell Anderson, author of
"What Price Glory," is. The author of "Margaret Fleming" was
concerned with the common people.
Herne Influenced By Ibsen
It has often been said Ibsen
exerted a great influence over
Herne. Hamlin Garland, who was
a close friend of the American
dramatist, said that while Herne
did not imitate the Norwegian,
Ibsen, he was greatly influenced by
him. It is believed that "Margaret
Fleming" is a conscious attempt to
introduce the Ibsen influence into
the American theatre.
vVhile at Princeton University,
Mr. Ewing was intensely interested
in the Little Theatre. He was a.
member of it for four years and an
officer of .it during his last two
·
·
years at t he university.
· ·Th e
Princeton Little Theatre has much
the same purpose as similar institutions at the Hopkins and Harvard, it was said. The productions

More Than 27 Houses Uncovered, Said Professor In
Lecture Tuesday

The present Sino-Jap war is testing the League of Nations and the
Kellogg Pact as they have never
been tested before, it was declared
by Dr. Henry Hodgkin, director of
the Pendle Hill School for social
and religious research, in his speech
"China, Japan, and Russia in Manchuria," presented Tuesday evening
before the University Supper Club.
League Has Made Mistake
The League, he declared, has
made a great mistake in not doing
something more concrete than it has
in regard to the current controversy
between Japan and China over
rights in Manchuria. Dr. Hodgkin
suggested, in his address, that a
commission of experts could have
long been sent to review the situation and could have mainstained orderby an international police force.
In discussing the League Dr.
Hodgkin questioned whether America can continue to stand out of the
League. It is a grave mistake for
her to do so, he pointed out. By
having joined the body in the · beginning America could have lifted
the League from the whirlpool of
European politics in which it has
become engulfed, the Supper Club
speaker asserted.
In his address the speaker also
discussed the geographical, political,
and economic conditions in Manchuria. Its climate, relatively small
population, and natural resources
make the country desirable to Russia, Japan, and China, who is, nominally, its sovereign, he said. The
facts that of the approximate :28,000,000 people in Manchuria, at
least 25,000,000 are Chinese and
that for centuries the dynasty ruling China was Manchurian gives
China preeminent rights there, Dr.
Hodgkin asserted.
Wars Have Resulted
The questioning of China's rights,
however, has resulted in several
major wars and the forcing oi
China into signing treaties drawn
up by both Russia and Japan.
Dr. Hodgkin also spoke Tuesday
at a graduate-faculty luncheon. His
topic was "The Nature and Value

Col. Stilwell Takes Post
Col. John Stilwell, vice-president
of the Consolidated Gas Co. of
New York, has accepted the invitation to become a member of advisory committee on gas engineering
at the Johns Hopkins.
He is to fill the place vacated by
th.e death last year of W. R. Addicks.

A new method of training white
rats, developed by the department
of psychology of the Johns Hopkins University, promises to simplify the work of studying the rat's
powers of discrimination, it was
said by Dr. Knight Dunlap, professor of experimental psychology,
yesterday.
In order to furnish sufficient incentive and gain the rat's attention
to the significant features of the
experiment, it was said, the Hopkins psychologists have devised a
new method of using electric shocks
in which the exciting and unpleasant features of the shock incite the
rat to appropriate action, instead of
deterring him.
Dunlap Explains Method
As explained by Dr. Dunlap, a
box is divided into halves by a
partition in which there is a small
doorway. The floor of each half
is a "grid" of metal bars, to wh.ich
alternating current is applied when
appropriate switches are closed.
By using high voltage ( l ,ooo to
I ,500 volts), and high resistance in
the circuit ( sev~ral million ohms),
the electrical resistance of the rat's
body is made neglible, an exactly
measured shock-current can be
used. The current used is scarcely
perceptible to a human being and,
from indications, not painful to the
rat. But because an electric shock
is strange to the rat it incites him
to get away from it.

EDITORIALS
THE JAYS AND TERRORS
Tonight at Homewood field the
r931 edition of the Hopkins football team will meet the Wes tern
Maryland aggregation. From all
the pre-game reports and sidelights,
the game should be a very exciting
one and neither team is given much
of an edge over the other. When
the final whistle blows, th.e score of
the victor, in all probability, will not
be more than a few points greater
than that of its opponent.
The Jays have had a very good
year so far and have not been defeated. In six games, the Jays have
amassed a total of r50 points, which
shows conclusively that they do not
lack the old scoring punch.
Last week against Doston College
the Terrors put up a nice fight, but
in the last quarter they broke and
the Bostonians were able to score a
victory over the Terrors by adding
another seven points to their score.
We think that the Jay line can
hold its own against the \Veslern
Maryland wall, and we believe that
the Marylanders will encounter
some difficulty in skirting our ends.
\Vestern Maryland's backfield is
probably a shade or two better than
ours, but they will strike a couple
snags when they attempt to stop
Pete Reynolds and Heni Beeler.
It's going to be a rip snorting tussle and every loyal Hopkins supporter should turn out with his
Yoice all tuned up and give the team
some sizable support.
The Jays have a batting average
of loo and here is a vote that says
they will come through tonight's
fracas with a clean slate-here's
hoping!

be reached and realizing full well
that it was absolutely necesary to
come to some agreement before
half of the eligible freshmen were
"sewed" up, passed last year's
agreement with a few added bylaws.
One of these by-laws particularly
interested us. It was to the effect
that no freshmen could ride in any
upper-classmen's automobile nor
could the upper-classmen ride in a
freshman's automobile. But (and
here is the prize work of the Board)
one exception to that rule was
made! It was brought to the
Board's attention that a certain
freshman, who lived several miles
from the University, had been in
the habit of riding to College every
morning with a certain fraternity
man. Privilege was asked by said
fraternity to be allowed to break the
ruling just passed, and continue to
bring said freshman into College
every morning. Before the fraternities had a chance to think about
it, the said privilege was granted to
the aforementioned fraternity.
Why any exception to the agreemen as passed, should be made to
any one fraternity, we can not s~e
and do not feel that it is in any way
fair to the other fraternities or the
Board. Rushing at Hopkins is not
supposed to be an obstacle race, in
which some certain fraternity is
given a handicap over all the others.
Each one is supposed to stand on
equal grounds with the others.
In the past each fraternity has
stood on its own feet and fought its
own battles-this is the first time
that any concessions have been
made to any one group in order to
nurse it along.
vVe feel that the action taken by
the Inferfraternity Board was extremely unwise and would suggest
to this body that they reconsider
the matter at their next meeting.

Dr. George Tischler, James he acted as assistant under ProfesSpeyer visiting professor in bot- sor Eriksson in the Botanical Inany at the Johns Hopkins Univer- stitute.
sity for the year 1931-32, praised
the emphasis laid upon graduate
work here and likened the Hopkins
to the German institutions of higher learning. . Having arrived at
Homewood last Monday, the German scientist will remain here as
lecturer until February of next
year.
Dr. Tischler was born on hi5
father's estate, Losgehnen, in East
Prussia on June 22, 1878. He lived
at home until the age of thirteen
years and obtained his elementary
education through tutors. He then
attended the high school at Bartenstein. In accordance with the German educational system, he remained here five years.

In 1896 he matriculated at the
Konigsberg University. He spent
one year there, and then a year at
l\Iunich University. In 1898 he
entered the University of Bonn.
There he remained for twelve years
,rst as a student, later as a member of the faculty. While at Bonn,
Dr. Tischler studied under the
eminent Professor Strassburger,
creator of the theory of cytology,
the theory of the cellular structure
of plants. He took his degree of
doctor of philosophy at Bonn in
1899.
From the university from which
he received his doctorate, the doctor
went to Heidelberg and became assistant in the Botanical Institute.
In October, 1902, he was promoted
to the position of a lecturer in the
university.

Contests To Be Sponsored

Since the beginning of the year,
the Interfraternity Board has been
attempting to come to some sort of
an agreement to regulate this season's rushing. Many plans were
submitted to the Board by different
individuals but none were able to
gather the needed support to become the ruling for the present
year. Among the plans brought up
was the agreement of last year. At
first this received only a half-hearted support of a few of the members.

It was announced by the journalistic fraternity that literary competitions will be sponsored by the
Hopkins chapter this year. These
contests, it was-explained, are to be
part of the organization's policy of
co-ordinating the work of the three
campus publications and to put them
on a higher plane.
The organization has as its aims
the promotion of collegiate journalism. Membership to the chapter at Homewood is restricted only
to those who have been actively engaged in publication work on the
campus.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1931

ROBINSON TELLS
OF EXCAVATIONS
IN OLYNTHUS
(Continued from page 1. col. 6)
One of the twelve mosaics found,
the lecturer stated, is probably the
earliest extant Hellenic pebble mosaic with a mythological representation. This parti'cular mosaic depicts Bellerophon riding on the
winged Pegasus and hurling a spear
at the Chimaera beneath him.
Colored Reproductions Being Made

According to the lecturer, colored
reproductions have been made of
these mosaics by one of the greatest artists in modern Greece, George
Vinto von Peschke. These documents are said by the director of
the American School in Athens to
be of the very highest importance
and to be an absolutely new thing
to laity and professionals alike who
hitherto have known only the Roman or Hellenistic tesselated work,
he said.
Of the 1222 coins found during
this season's e~~avations less than
25 are post-classical, it was pointed
out by Dr. Robinson. More than
hlf of the coins ( 92 silver and 545
bronze) are of the Chalcidic
League.
The House of the Comedianso called because of a terra-cotta
figure of an actor found in excavating it-is a good example of the
more luxurious type of Olynthian
home, said Dr. Robinson. The
house, which measures about 50
feet square and which contains perhaps ten rooms on the ground floor,
is of sun-dried mud-brick. Within
the house the walls are coated by
smooth-finished stucco in various
bright colors. The roof was found
to be covered with reel clay tiles.
It was in the House of the Comedian, said the lecturer, that there
was found the first bay window
ever to be discovered in a classical
house.
Houses Built At Sarne Time

Because of the similarity in plan
ancl construction the Hopkins professor is led to believe, he indicated, that the houses were all built
about the same time, toward the
encl of the fifth century, and by one
architeqt. The houses were not
numbered, the speaker said, but
were named after· their owners.
"Vve shall indeed have to revise
the accepted belief that until the
Hellenistic Age the Greeks lived in
petty little towns and houses like
so many wasps' nests and had no
important domestic architecture,"
declared Dr. Robinson.
Business District Found

On the South Hill, what is believed by the archaeologist to be
the business district of the .ancient
city, was found many irregular
streets and many architecturally
mimportant one-roomed shops were
excavated by the party. More than
20 deep grainaries excavated in the
native conglomerate and containing
a new type Df sub-Mycenean native
Olynthian pottery, were also cleared
in this section. Two cemeteries
were located after a long search but
proved to be of great importance,
it was pointed out.
It was revealed to the Robinsonheaded group of excavators, after
200 graves in one cemetery were
opened, that inhumation and cremation were practiced side by side in
Olynthus.
The 1931 excavations were the
second period of work undertaken
by the Hopkins archaeologist and
his group. Fifteen graduate students of the university accompanied
Dr. Robinson. About 350 workmen, mostly Asia Minor refugees
who were paid about 50 cents per
day, wielded the spade. and other
excavating tools while the experts
looked on, noting the things which
were being unearthed by the workmen.

Dr. Oliver's New Book,
'Article Thirty-Two,'
Appeared Recently
"Article Thirty-Two," a new
book written by Dr. John R. Oliver,
noted psychiatrist and criminologist, has just appeared. It is "a
study of a clerical family and the
effect of its 'unhealthy atmosphers'
on a boy and girl who grew up in
it." The book is now in its second
printing.
The warden of Alumni Memorial Hall, who was born at Albany,
N. Y., in 1872, received his A. B.
at Harvard in 1894. Since 1917
he has been the chief medical officer
to the Supreme Bench of Baltimore
and during 1914-15 served as a surgeon in the Austrian army. He has
now gained prominence as a
psychiatrist at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital and as a State criminologist.
In 1915 he published his first book
called "The Good Shepherd." The
next of his publications came out in
r9r7 and was entitled "The SixPointecl Cross in the Dust." The
best known of all his wG>rks are
"Fear" and "Victim and Victor"
which were published in 1927 and
1928 respectively.

Pleased By Work Being Done In 1931 Production, "Secret
Service," He Takes Chance To Give Advice to Coaches

"Pop" Swindell, one of the early
directors of the Barnstormers, attended the rehearsal of "Secret
Service," the 1931 production, last
Sunday afternoon.
"Pop" Is Pleased

William Banks, who was directing the rehearsal, ran off the first
set for "Pop" to give him an idea
of what the show at the Lyric, December 4 and S will be like. When
the act was completed, it is said,
Swindell appeared to be pleased.
He gave his opinions to Banks and
some advice to several of the actors.
When they proceeded to the third
act, "Pop" himself got into action
and did some directing of his own.
He vividly demonstrated how some
of the moods should be expressed,
and also helped Banks work out
some of the technicalities of the
stage directing.
To ''Pop" is attributed the reason
for the rapid development of the
Hopkins dramatic organization.

Representatives from the Johns
Hopkins University to the Intercollegiate Model Disarmament Conference, to be held at the Bucknell
University in December, will be announced next week, it was learned
today.
Five men will be chosen to represent the Johns Hopkins in the
discussion of the armament policies
of the nations of the world. Just
what nations this University will
represent has as yet not been announced.
Five phases of the armament
policies of different countries will
be discussed at the conference by
representatives of universities all
over the country: land armaments,
naval armaments, budgetary reduction, aviation, and chemical warfare.

There won't be any soft pickings for Hopkins tonight, when
Western Maryland's eleven steps
on the field. Those Westminster
boys' ability will demand the
greatest respect from the Jays.
For several seasons the Green
Terrors have been represented by
teams that have tackled one
major opponent after the other
and still they've come out the
victor. Two years ago, they went
through the season without either a
loss or a tie.
Terrors Swamped st. John's
This year it seemed that the
Terrors were in for another
banner season, but the forecasts
did not turn out to be very
accurate.
Georgetown humbled
them 25-7, but only after a great
rally in the last quarter.
After the Washington and Jefferson tussle Western Maryland was
seized with that football enigma,
m1ury. Koppe, their mighty fullback, had to watch the Duquesne
game from the sidelines, but the
Terrors managed to play a scoreless
tie.
Lost To Boston College
More injuries resulted from
this and the Loyola game until
as many as four regulars were
incapacitated. Still Coac;h Harlow was able to put a team on
the field, last Saturday, that was
strong ·enough to fight but lose
by a 19-13 score to a smart Boston College eleven.
Tonight, it seems probable
that Western Maryland will
again be able to present its fullest strength.
Most of the injured men-Sadusky, Wallace,
Kleinman and perhaps Joneshave
recuperated
sufficiently
from their ailments to get back
into gridiron paraphenalia.
To-Nite's Game A Toss-Up
. means t h at H op k"ms w11··1
Th 1s
tackle its toughest opponent to
date. The line-plunging ability
of Koppe is, already a byword in
these Parts' W hile the trick)' balltoting of Jimmy Dunne will undoubtedly add several thrills to
the contest.
Fortunately the Jay line-up
will again be intact. Captain
Helm will be back at his center
post while Pete Reynolds' hand
injury has just about healed.
Despite the powerful offense
that Hopkins displayed last week,
our respect for Western Maryland's strength, displayed against
stronger opponents than the
Jays have encountered, permits
us to go no further than say we
hope the Black and Blue will retain its clear slate.

Herne' s Breaking A way From
Melodrama To Be Considered In Talk
S. Blaine Ewing, instructor in
English at the Johns Hopkins University, will lecture next Monday
at 8 :3o P. M., at the Playshop, on
"American Drama at the End of
the Nineteenth Century."
In his lecture, Mr. Ewing, who
has been at the Hopkins since 1930,
will speak of the attempt of James
A. Herne, author of "Margaret
Fleming," to break away from the
absurd melodrama so rampant at
that period. Berne's plays dealt
with people who were living. On
the other hand, it was pointed out,
Herne was not a realist in the sense
that Maxwell Anderson, author of
"What Price Glory," is. The author of "Margaret Fleming" was
concerned with the common people.
Herne Influenced By Ibsen
It has often been said Ibsen
exerted a great influence over
Herne. Hamlin Garland, who was
a close friend of the American
dramatist, said that while Herne
did not imitate the Norwegian,
Ibsen, he was greatly influenced by
him. It is believed that "Margaret
Fleming" is a conscious attempt to
introduce the Ibsen influence into
the American theatre.
vVhile at Princeton University,
Mr. Ewing was intensely interested
in the Little Theatre. He was a.

officer of .it during his last two

The present Sino-Jap war is testing the League of Nations and the
Kellogg Pact as they have never
been tested before, it was declared
by Dr. Henry Hodgkin, director of
the Pendle Hill School for social
and religious research, in his speech
"China, Japan, and Russia in Manchuria," presented Tuesday evening
before the University Supper Club.
League Has Made Mistake
The League, he declared, has
made a great mistake in not doing
something more concrete than it has
in regard to the current controversy
between Japan and China over
rights in Manchuria. Dr. Hodgkin
suggested, in his address, that a
commission of experts could have
long been sent to review the situation and could have mainstained orderby an international police force.
In discussing the League Dr.
Hodgkin questioned whether America can continue to stand out of the
League. It is a grave mistake for
her to do so, he pointed out. By
having joined the body in the · beginning America could have lifted
the League from the whirlpool of
European politics in which it has
become engulfed, the Supper Club
speaker asserted.
In his address the speaker also
discussed the geographical, political,
and economic conditions in Manchuria. Its climate, relatively small
population, and natural resources
make the country desirable to Russia, Japan, and China, who is, nominally, its sovereign, he said. The
facts that of the approximate :28,000,000 people in Manchuria, at
least 25,000,000 are Chinese and
that for centuries the dynasty ruling China was Manchurian gives
China preeminent rights there, Dr.
Hodgkin asserted.
Wars Have Resulted
The questioning of China's rights,
however, has resulted in several
major wars and the forcing oi
China into signing treaties drawn
up by both Russia and Japan.

A new method of training white
rats, developed by the department
of psychology of the Johns Hopkins University, promises to simplify the work of studying the rat's
powers of discrimination, it was
said by Dr. Knight Dunlap, professor of experimental psychology,
yesterday.
In order to furnish sufficient incentive and gain the rat's attention
to the significant features of the
experiment, it was said, the Hopkins psychologists have devised a
new method of using electric shocks
in which the exciting and unpleasant features of the shock incite the
rat to appropriate action, instead of
deterring him.
Dunlap Explains Method
As explained by Dr. Dunlap, a
box is divided into halves by a
partition in which there is a small
doorway. The floor of each half
is a "grid" of metal bars, to wh.ich
alternating current is applied when
appropriate switches are closed.
By using high voltage ( l ,ooo to
I ,500 volts), and high resistance in
the circuit ( sev~ral million ohms),
the electrical resistance of the rat's
body is made neglible, an exactly
measured shock-current can be
used. The current used is scarcely
perceptible to a human being and,
from indications, not painful to the
rat. But because an electric shock
is strange to the rat it incites him
to get away from it.

EDITORIALS
THE JAYS AND TERRORS
Tonight at Homewood field the
r931 edition of the Hopkins football team will meet the Wes tern
Maryland aggregation. From all
the pre-game reports and sidelights,
the game should be a very exciting
one and neither team is given much
of an edge over the other. When
the final whistle blows, th.e score of
the victor, in all probability, will not
be more than a few points greater
than that of its opponent.
The Jays have had a very good
year so far and have not been defeated. In six games, the Jays have
amassed a total of r50 points, which
shows conclusively that they do not
lack the old scoring punch.
Last week against Doston College
the Terrors put up a nice fight, but
in the last quarter they broke and
the Bostonians were able to score a
victory over the Terrors by adding
another seven points to their score.
We think that the Jay line can
hold its own against the \Veslern
Maryland wall, and we believe that
the Marylanders will encounter
some difficulty in skirting our ends.
\Vestern Maryland's backfield is
probably a shade or two better than
ours, but they will strike a couple
snags when they attempt to stop
Pete Reynolds and Heni Beeler.
It's going to be a rip snorting tussle and every loyal Hopkins supporter should turn out with his
Yoice all tuned up and give the team
some sizable support.
The Jays have a batting average
of loo and here is a vote that says
they will come through tonight's
fracas with a clean slate-here's
hoping!

be reached and realizing full well
that it was absolutely necesary to
come to some agreement before
half of the eligible freshmen were
"sewed" up, passed last year's
agreement with a few added bylaws.
One of these by-laws particularly
interested us. It was to the effect
that no freshmen could ride in any
upper-classmen's automobile nor
could the upper-classmen ride in a
freshman's automobile. But (and
here is the prize work of the Board)
one exception to that rule was
made! It was brought to the
Board's attention that a certain
freshman, who lived several miles
from the University, had been in
the habit of riding to College every
morning with a certain fraternity
man. Privilege was asked by said
fraternity to be allowed to break the
ruling just passed, and continue to
bring said freshman into College
every morning. Before the fraternities had a chance to think about
it, the said privilege was granted to
the aforementioned fraternity.
Why any exception to the agreemen as passed, should be made to
any one fraternity, we can not s~e
and do not feel that it is in any way
fair to the other fraternities or the
Board. Rushing at Hopkins is not
supposed to be an obstacle race, in
which some certain fraternity is
given a handicap over all the others.
Each one is supposed to stand on
equal grounds with the others.
In the past each fraternity has
stood on its own feet and fought its
own battles-this is the first time
that any concessions have been
made to any one group in order to
nurse it along.
vVe feel that the action taken by
the Inferfraternity Board was extremely unwise and would suggest
to this body that they reconsider
the matter at their next meeting.

ROBINSON TELLS
OF EXCAVATIONS
IN OLYNTHUS
(Continued from page 1. col. 6)
One of the twelve mosaics found,
the lecturer stated, is probably the
earliest extant Hellenic pebble mosaic with a mythological representation. This parti'cular mosaic depicts Bellerophon riding on the
winged Pegasus and hurling a spear
at the Chimaera beneath him.
Colored Reproductions Being Made

According to the lecturer, colored
reproductions have been made of
these mosaics by one of the greatest artists in modern Greece, George
Vinto von Peschke. These documents are said by the director of
the American School in Athens to
be of the very highest importance
and to be an absolutely new thing
to laity and professionals alike who
hitherto have known only the Roman or Hellenistic tesselated work,
he said.
Of the 1222 coins found during
this season's e~~avations less than
25 are post-classical, it was pointed
out by Dr. Robinson. More than
hlf of the coins ( 92 silver and 545
bronze) are of the Chalcidic
League.
The House of the Comedianso called because of a terra-cotta
figure of an actor found in excavating it-is a good example of the
more luxurious type of Olynthian
home, said Dr. Robinson. The
house, which measures about 50
feet square and which contains perhaps ten rooms on the ground floor,
is of sun-dried mud-brick. Within
the house the walls are coated by
smooth-finished stucco in various
bright colors. The roof was found
to be covered with reel clay tiles.
It was in the House of the Comedian, said the lecturer, that there
was found the first bay window
ever to be discovered in a classical
house.
Houses Built At Sarne Time

Because of the similarity in plan
ancl construction the Hopkins professor is led to believe, he indicated, that the houses were all built
about the same time, toward the
encl of the fifth century, and by one
architeqt. The houses were not
numbered, the speaker said, but
were named after· their owners.
"Vve shall indeed have to revise
the accepted belief that until the
Hellenistic Age the Greeks lived in
petty little towns and houses like
so many wasps' nests and had no
important domestic architecture,"
declared Dr. Robinson.
Business District Found

On the South Hill, what is believed by the archaeologist to be
the business district of the .ancient
city, was found many irregular
streets and many architecturally
mimportant one-roomed shops were
excavated by the party. More than
20 deep grainaries excavated in the
native conglomerate and containing
a new type Df sub-Mycenean native
Olynthian pottery, were also cleared
in this section. Two cemeteries
were located after a long search but
proved to be of great importance,
it was pointed out.
It was revealed to the Robinsonheaded group of excavators, after
200 graves in one cemetery were
opened, that inhumation and cremation were practiced side by side in
Olynthus.
The 1931 excavations were the
second period of work undertaken
by the Hopkins archaeologist and
his group. Fifteen graduate students of the university accompanied
Dr. Robinson. About 350 workmen, mostly Asia Minor refugees
who were paid about 50 cents per
day, wielded the spade. and other
excavating tools while the experts
looked on, noting the things which
were being unearthed by the workmen.

Dr. Oliver's New Book,
'Article Thirty-Two,'
Appeared Recently
"Article Thirty-Two," a new
book written by Dr. John R. Oliver,
noted psychiatrist and criminologist, has just appeared. It is "a
study of a clerical family and the
effect of its 'unhealthy atmosphers'
on a boy and girl who grew up in
it." The book is now in its second
printing.
The warden of Alumni Memorial Hall, who was born at Albany,
N. Y., in 1872, received his A. B.
at Harvard in 1894. Since 1917
he has been the chief medical officer
to the Supreme Bench of Baltimore
and during 1914-15 served as a surgeon in the Austrian army. He has
now gained prominence as a
psychiatrist at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital and as a State criminologist.
In 1915 he published his first book
called "The Good Shepherd." The
next of his publications came out in
r9r7 and was entitled "The SixPointecl Cross in the Dust." The
best known of all his wG>rks are
"Fear" and "Victim and Victor"
which were published in 1927 and
1928 respectively.

Swindell, Early 'Stormer
Dire~tor, Attends Rehearsal

WARNER & CO.
OUR NEW PRICES---

Pleased By Work Being Done In 1931 Production, "Secret
Service," He Takes Chance To Give Advice to Coaches
And Actors Last Sunday
"Pop" Swindell, one of the early
directors of the Barnstormers, attended the rehearsal of "Secret
Service," the 1931 production, last
Sunday afternoon.
"Pop" Is Pleased

William Banks, who was directing the rehearsal, ran off the first
set for "Pop" to give him an idea
of what the show at the Lyric, December 4 and S will be like. When
the act was completed, it is said,
Swindell appeared to be pleased.
He gave his opinions to Banks and
some advice to several of the actors.
When they proceeded to the third
act, "Pop" himself got into action
and did some directing of his own.
He vividly demonstrated how some
of the moods should be expressed,
and also helped Banks work out
some of the technicalities of the
stage directing.
To ''Pop" is attributed the reason
for the rapid development of the
Hopkins dramatic organization.

Representatives from the Johns
Hopkins University to the Intercollegiate Model Disarmament Conference, to be held at the Bucknell
University in December, will be announced next week, it was learned
today.
Five men will be chosen to represent the Johns Hopkins in the
discussion of the armament policies
of the nations of the world. Just
what nations this University will
represent has as yet not been announced.
Five phases of the armament
policies of different countries will
be discussed at the conference by
representatives of universities all
over the country: land armaments,
naval armaments, budgetary reduction, aviation, and chemical warfare.

In his address presented yesterdayday at Homewood, Arthur Garfield Hays, noted criminal lawyer,
described his observations and impressions of Russia, which he
toured some time ago with a party
of friends.
"I found the bourgeoisie in Russia far less opposed to the Communist regime than the bourgeoisie
elsewhere," he said. "I found the
Communists far less certain and assured than Radicals elsewhere. Russia is a workingman's country; it is
not a workingman's paradise.
Impressed By Beauty

"Arriving in Moscow, one is immediately impressed by the beauty
and strangeness of the city, by the
huge buildings and gardens of the
Kremlin, surrounded by the ancient
walls, but chiefly by the democracy
of the atmosphere. The people are
comfortably dressed; they seem
happy and alive.
